titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. I called this morning to see Mr. Martin, who has been sometime very unwell— Found Mr: B. Cramer, and another Gentleman with him— I afterwards walk’d from the Winter Palace to the Foundery on the Quay; and rode home— I was so unwell the whole day, that I wavered in mind whether to go to Count Romanzoff’s supper, or to send an excuse, both for myself and Mrs: Adams, who was too sick to go— I delayed however sending the excuse, untill it was too late— I went at 9. in the Evening— There were about twenty ladies, besides the Princess Amelia, and perhaps forty Gentlemen— The foreign Ministers and Ministers of the Country principally. There were Cards, but no dancing— I pass’d the Evening in Conversation with Count Stedingk—Chevalier de Navarro—Count Soltykoff, and some others; among whom was Count John Potocki a man of Letters— Supper was served about Midnight; and was very magnificent— I came home between one and two in the Morning; quite sick.— Count Romanzoff introduced me to the Princess Amelia.

2. Mr Harris had been part of last Evening with us; and I had agreed if I should be well enough this morning to go with him to the Book-store of the Academy of Sciences, and to see Mr: Thelisius— But I was so ill, on rising this morning that I sent word to Mr: Harris, I could not go— I had a violent inflammation in my left eye, which continued increasing the whole of this day, and was severely painful— At Night the eye was almost closed; much swolen, and deeply inflamed— At the same time I find myself with a wound on my right leg; how or when received I know not, but which also inflames— With this I have great thirst and some fever— Mrs: Adams was likewise very ill the whole day with one of her severest head-aches; and an inflammation and swelling in one of her ears, which has been sometime troublesome to her— Dr: Galloway was here twice this day, and prescribed for us both.— I received this day from Mr: Gotthelf Fischer Secretary of the Society of Enquirers into Natural History a letter, with a Diploma for me, as an ordinary member of that Society; and a couple of pamphlets

3. All our young Gentlemen dined with Mr: Raimbert— I sent an excuse to the Ambassador, whose great diplomatic dinner I could not attend— The inflammation in my eye increased a little in the Night; but not much— It continued nearly the same all this day; but towards Night began to subside— That of my leg continued increasing, and the soreness was so great that I could no longer walk upon it— I pass’d almost the whole of the day, as I did yesterday upon my bed— Catherine read to me the remainder of the Mysteries of Udolpho: the fourth volume of which I had left unfinished— Mrs: Adams though yet quite ill, was better this day than yesterday— Mrs: Krehmer called this day, to ask permission of Mrs: Adams, to take Charles with her on Monday next at twelve O’Clock, on a visit to the Princess Amelia— To which Mrs: Adams very readily consented.

4. I had a tolerable Night’s rest, and the inflammation of my eye subsided considerably during the course of the Night. it did not increase again during this day; though having received this morning a file of the Boston Patriot, from the day when we left home untill the 4th: of November, I could not keep my eyes from them, and was reading them two or three hours— Mr: Six, the Minister of Holland called and pass’d an hour with me this Morning— He told me the Ambassador’s great dinner yesterday was to the members of the new Council of the Empire— And that the intended marriage of the Emperor Napoleon, with the eldest daughter of the Emperor of Austria has been officially announced— We were to have dined this day at Monsieur Colombi’s— But were obliged to send an apology, both for Mrs: Adams, and for myself.— Mr: Harris was here this Evening.

5. Mrs: Adams after the application not very successfully of a blister, finds herself however much better— The inflammation of my eye, has almost but not yet entirely subsided— That of my leg continues much as it has been— I cannot walk; nor even stand upon it without pain.— Some remains of fever, are also still perceptible— I cannot yet write at all; and can read but little— I still pass most of my time on my bed.— Soon after noon, Mrs: Krehmer called,
according to her appointment, and took Charles with her upon a visit to the Princess Amelia of Baden, the Sister of the Empress— About two hours afterwards she sent him home again— The Emperor and Empress had both been in the Princess her Apartment during his visit, and taken much notice of him.

6. Received this morning a number of American newspapers to the last of November, forwarded to me by Mr: Jonathan Russell, and brought by Mr: Adgate, who arrived last Evening— I was employed all the morning in reading them— Mr: Harris, Captain Beckford, and Captain Donaldson paid me visits.— My eye seems entirely recovered; or at least as well as it was before this illness; but my leg will not yet allow me to walk.

7. I was invited to a great Diplomatic dinner this day at the Baron de Blome the Danish Ministers; but was obliged to send him an apology— This Evening there was a Ball given at the musical Club; attended by the Emperor and all the Imperial family.— Our Ladies and Gentlemen also attended it; excepting Mr: Gray, who kept me company at home, and with whom I played a game of chess— Mr: Harris was here several times in the course of the day.

8. The Ladies came home at about 2. this morning.— I had visits this forenoon, from the French Ambassador—and the Baron de Blome; from Count Bussche—Mr: Six, and Mr: Harris— For the first time since the supper at Count Romanzoff’s, I took a ride in the Carriage— Mrs: Adams and Charles went with me— The family were all invited to a Ball this Evening at the French Ambassador’s which they accordingly all attended— They went about 9. O’Clock, before which I played chess with Mr: Everett.— My time passes heavily and in total idleness.

9. I took this morning a long ride with Mrs: Adams and Charles; was able for the first time since the beginning of the month to write, and accordingly did write; and flattered myself that I was altogether recovered, untill this Evening, when I found that the soreness and inflammation in my leg had returned so as to threaten me with several days more of Confinement. Endeavoured to amuse the Evening with Cards— We are now in the midst of the Russian Carnaval; which continues only about a week— The Ice-hills and booths upon the river opposite the quay, are crowded with people in pursuit of Sport, and the quay itself is covered with walkers of all descriptions—

10. I found my leg so much inflamed this morning, and so sore that I could neither stand upon it; nor bear a stocking over it— I was obliged to lay almost the whole day on my bed, and could do nothing but read—happily my eye has so far recovered as to enable me to do this— In the Evening I played chess with Mr: Smith— Mr: Harris and Mr: Adgate paid me a visit but I could not see them— I read a small astronomical treatise in German, by Bode, lent me by Mr: Six— I read also some pages in the first volume of Robison’s Elements of mechanical philosophy.

11. I was again obliged to confine myself the whole of this day to my bed; and by the advice of Dr: Galloway to use a continual fomentation of lead-water mixed with Brandy upon my leg— I read Robison’s book and French Newspapers— Chess in the Evening. The Russian Carnival finishes this day— There was a Mascarade at 11. in the Morning— A French play, which began at 2. in the afternoon; and a second Mascarade at 9. in the Evening.— The warmth of the weather, with rain, has spoiled the ice-hills— But the crowds upon the quay, which is frequented also by the imperial family have been as usual— My confinement has prevented me from seeing any thing of it— Mr: Harris was here again this day, but I could not see him.

12. I was this day, able to rise and dress myself, and pass’d the time chiefly upon the Sopha— Took a ride however in the carriage, and amused the Evening with Cards— Mr: Harris and Dr: Galloway were here— I found however at Night on going to bed that I had exercised my leg too much, and that the inflammation had returned with additional heat. I find occasion for the exercise of Patience, in proportion as I have been deficient in Prudence.

13. I had a very restless and feverish Night, and had some fever all this day— The inflammation and swelling of my leg has been greater than at any time heretofore— I pass’d the day almost entirely in reading, for I cannot write more than barely to keep along the current of my Journal— In the Evening I played chess, with Mr: Smith— There were two Mascarades at Night; one of which the Gentlemen, except Mr: Gray, attended— They are for strangers only and close the carnival— But the Russian lent commenced yesterday.

14. My fever returned again immediately after dinner, and with it the inflammation in my leg, though I have steadily continued the use of the lead water, and lay almost the whole of this day upon my bed— I had about five years ago, at Quincy a similar fever with an inflammation in my thumb, which from as slight a wound as that now in my leg was a full month in healing— Mr: Harris was here this Evening— I played chess with Mr: Everett—employed the whole day in reading.

15. I ceased this day using lead-water to disperse the inflammation of my leg, finding it altogether insufficient to check its progress; and substituted in its stead an application of fresh butter— I sat up the greater part of the day, and took a ride in the carriage— I likewise ventured to employ some part of my time in writing. But at night I found the ill effect of this course by a considerable increase of the inflammation— Amused the Evening by playing chess

16. After a good Night’s rest, I found my complaint in my leg so much aggravated that I was obliged again to return to the system of confinement on the bed; and instead of butter to substitute by Dr: Galloway’s advice an application of Turner’s Cerate— I also took a strong drastic dose of medicine— Mr: Harris was here in the Evening— I pass’d it again at Chess. I have every Night a high fever with a strong perspiration.

17. Had a very indifferent Night’s rest, being for great part of it deprived of sleep by the pulsations of a nervous fever. The inflammation upon my leg appears this day to have come to a stand; so as neither to advance nor to recede— I confined myself again the whole day upon my bed—leaving it only twice for about a quarter of an hour each time to see Mr: Raimbert, who paid me a visit; and one of the Gentlemen messengers from M. de Maisonneuve who brought me a letter to be sent to America— Mr: Harris also paid me a visit, and informed me of a Convention signed yesterday by M. Navarro the Chargé d’Affaires of Portugal with a Commissioner of this Government;— I find it difficult to write even so much from day to day as may keep pace with the lapse of time, in minuting down the diary of a sick chamber— I went this night very early to bed in the hope of escaping my fever; but was disappointed.

18. My fever was very troublesome almost the Night through, and allowed me scarcely any sleep: but the inflammation upon my leg is at length manifestly and decisively upon the decline— I continued this whole day extended upon my bed: with scarcely the interval of half an hour. I found myself reduced to a state of extreme weakness, and was obliged to resort to a strengthening cordial— Mr: Harris called upon me in the Evening. I read in Coxe’s travels; and also the Sermon, and the fragment of Massillon, upon Communion.

19. I was able to sit up a small part of this day, and had a visit of half an hour from Mr: Six— Mr: Cutts called upon me twice; and I gave him a Passport— He is going this Evening for Archangel— I read part of the third volume of Coxe’s travels, which are a sort of Salmagundi— A Dish of Dissertations upon subjects relating to Russia— In the Evening I played Chess with Mr: Everett.— The coldness of the weather prevented me from riding out.

20. Sat up great part of this day, and rode out with Mrs: Adams;— I began also to write again, but could not do much of that. I had a short visit from Baron Blome, and a long one from General Pardo; who begins to despair of the Cause of the Junta in Spain.— Mr: Harris also paid me a visit this Evening— I received a letter from a merchant at Odessa—mentioning the arrival of an American vessel there; which Mr: Harris appeared to disapprove— I played a game of chess with Mr: Gray.

21. I was up the whole day, and took a ride in the Carriage; but I am yet unable to walk— Wrote a little; and drafted an answer to a note from Count Romanzoff which I received more than a fortnight ago— Mr: Harris was here in the Evening—

22. At length I am enabled to resume my usual cloathing; and to walk about the house— I also rode out alone; and called at Mr: Meyer’s; to settle my former draft, and to make a new one— I was up the whole day; but found I could not write so much as usual— Mr: Six paid us a long visit in the Evening, and is in full expectation of a satisfactory settlement of the affairs of his Country— He speaks of passing the Summer here, as of a certainty— I sent this day my answer to Count Romanzoff’s note.

23. Mr: M’Murtrie called upon me this morning to inform me that he should go the day after to-morrow for Hamburg; with the intention of embarking there for England— He offered to take my dispatches, and requested a letter of Introduction to Genl: Armstrong— I received also this morning from Count Romanzoff a note mentioning with much satisfaction the arrival of an American vessel at Odessa; directly from Baltimore— The first American vessel that has appeared on the Black Sea. I rode out this morning with Catherine; Mrs: Adams being unwell— Wrote part of a letter to the Secretary of State— Mr: Harris was here in the Evening.

24. Rode with Mrs: Adams to the great shops, and made finally a purchase of some plate— Pass’d the remainder of the day at home in writing to America, and preparing the letters for Mr: M’Murtrie— There was a Ball this Evening at the Chevalier de Bray’s, which our Gentlemen attended— I was glad to be furnished with an excuse— I can take no pleasure in parties, the sole amusements of which are dancing and gambling at cards or dice—and which begin at 11. at Night.

25. Mr: M’Murtrie, Mr: Martin and Mr: Fisher called upon me this morning— I gave Mr: M’Murtrie the letters and dispatches for America; with that which he had requested for Genl: Armstrong— Mr: Harris was afterwards here; with a letter of unpleasant intelligence from Mr: Waters at Paris— I walked out, for the first time since the first day of this month— I went as far as the Winter Palace, and found myself too much fatigued to go farther— Mr: Smith dined at Mr: Krehmer’s— The other Gentlemen, with the Ladies went this Evening to a Concert with which they were much pleased— There was also a Ball at Mr: H. Severin’s, which the Gentlemen attended— I read Massillon’s Sermon upon the Passion; and part of a Volume of Coxe’s travels in Russia— Wrote a Note to Count Romanzoff.

26. I took a long walk this morning.— Longer than was advisable from the length of time that I have been confined, and unable to walk— In the Evening I found myself much fatigued— Mr: Harris dined and passed the Evening with us— We had Cards, and Chess— I answered the letter from Mr: Fischer the Director of the Imperial Society of Naturalists at Moscow; which I received on the day when I was taken ill.

27. I went to Count Romanzoff’s this morning, at eleven O’Clock, the hour that he had appointed in consequence of my request for an interview with him— I found Mr: d’Alopeus and Mr: Benkendorff with him; who retired immediately upon my going into his cabinet— He said they were both on the point of going to Naples, and had come to ask him for Passports— As to Mr: Benkendorf he was a young man, who might form himself there in the diplomatic career, as well as any where; but he was inclined to put off the departure of Mr: d’Alopeus, as long as he could— He did not like to see him go to Naples— He had all proper respect for the king of Naples; but the relations of that Country with this, were not of sufficient importance to require that they should be confided to Mr: d’Alopeus, whom he considered as one of the ablest diplomatic characters of this Empire.
The Chargé d’Affaires of Naples, he said; had sent to request an interview with him— He supposed it was to inform him of the appointment of a new Minister here, which he understood had taken place— The Duke de Mondragone, on account of his own domestic affairs; or for some reason of that kind not desiring to return here— The Count then enquired what was the object upon which I had desired to see him— I told him it was on the case of the American vessel the Intercourse; which had been condemned by the Commission for neutral Navigation at Archangel; upon which Mr: Harris had sometime since presented to him a note; and which at a former interview I had also mentioned to him— I assured him that the vessel and Cargo were undoubtedly American property; and dwelt upon all the alleviating Circumstances which could be adduced to prevail upon him to have the proceeds of the sale restored to the owner, Mr: Cutts— I observed to him that this had been suggested as a probable indulgence to Mr: Cutts, by the Commissioners themselves; as he had assured me— That one motive for the condemnation was the vessel’s having touched at Gottenburg, on her way from Bilbao— But that she had arrived just at the time of the conclusion of Peace; and at a time when I had heard that other vessels had been admitted— He said this must be a mistake— That no vessels whatever had been admitted from Sweden before the signature of the Treaty at Frederickshamm; and that during the negotiations there had not even been an armistice.— The other ground of condemnation was the want of a rôle d’equipage, which I said was to be accounted for from the length of time since the vessel had left the United States; and the changes in the crew which had been necessary— The Count promised to attend to the subject, and intimated that they were in discussion with another friendly power, on similar cases— On the whole there is very little chance for the restoration of Mr: Cutts’s property— I then told the Count of the recent intelligence from Denmark; that a new Ordinance respecting privateers, was about to be issued; and that a large number of privateers was fitting out in the Ports of Denmark.— I spoke of the anxiety which it occasioned among the Americans now here, and who propose returning to America with Cargoes of the produce of this Country— Though inclining to think this apprehension without foundation, I said I was myself fearful it might interrupt the freedom of Navigation of our vessels that would be coming here; and I said that as this was an object interesting to this Country as well as to us, perhaps an intimation might be given to the Court of Denmark, from this Government which would operate as a restraint upon the Danes, and afford some protection to our trade— The Count said that if the free course of vessels coming to this Country should be obstructed they might no doubt address reclamations to the Danish Government; but that as to an ordinance for privateers, it was hardly possible to make any objection against such a measure as that— Denmark was probably stimulated to it by France; and it was impossible that there should be any security for Commerce untill England should incline to terms of Peace— What should now prevent this he could not conceive— Spain had heretofore been alledged, as a cause for declining Negotiation—but Spain was now entirely subdued; Cadix alone excepted— The English army had abandoned its defence, and had retired into Portugal— What could now be the motive for persisting in the War; unless it was the mere pleasure of perpetual hostility— A system which could hardly be supposed, as the intention of any Government. The Count enquired what was the present state of our affairs with France and with England?— I told him that I had no recent intelligence— That extracts from English newspapers had announced that Mr: Pinkney our Minister at London, had left that City and embarked for America; but I had no authentic information to that effect— That from America I had no accounts of any thing important since the rupture of the negotiations with Mr: Jackson, but that if as appeared
from the latest accounts from England, the British Government was really inclined to a settlement of differences with America, I presumed it would be accomplished; especially as the violence with which France and her dependences were proceeding towards us, would exasperate the Spirits of the People against them, and make them more readily incline to conciliation with England— That the conduct of France towards us was unaccountable— That if we were at open War with her, she could do us no more injury that she now does; and that we should then at least enjoy the advantage of a free trade with England. The Count said that it was not for him to account for the motives by which a foreign government might be guided; but he could see no rational ground for the proceedings of France towards America— He asked whether it was true that so much American property had been confiscated at Naples— I told him, not only at Naples, but in Holland, in France, in Spain; wherever they could lay their hands upon our property they had taken it; and without any possible motive other, than the determination to plunder. He said he hoped at least they had not got the vessels at Cadix, of which he had seen in the English newspapers that there were a great number— I said I hoped at least they would escape— He said, that he saw by another article in the English papers that the French Toulon fleet was out; and that an action between them and Lord Collingwood was expected— I told him I was sorry to hear it; as the issue of such an action would undoubtedly be the same as that of all their naval battles, in the present war, and would only tend to buoy up the temper of the English people, for a further continuance of the War; without producing any imaginable good— He said it would have the further ill-effect of destroying the remnant of any counterpoise to the naval force of Great-Britain—without which it seemed impossible to expect a permanent Peace— I observed that it appeared probable there would be a change in the British Ministry; as they had been several times left in the minority in the House of Commons; and it was very difficult for a Ministry to stand against a majority or even with a small majority in that House— As the Ministers usually had the Prudence to retire while they could command a majority to sanction their proceedings— But, said the Count, it does not follow that a change of men, will be a change of Ministry— Should Mr: Canning for example come in again, it would not be a change of ministry— And even if Lord Grenville should come in, it is doubtful whether it would be such a change as to produce Peace— Lord Grenville was the principal personage in a Ministry which commenced and carried on the War that laid the foundation for all those of the present times— He may be called emphatically the man of the War; and in his late Speeches in Parliament he seems to blame the Ministers only for pursuing a different system of War, from that which he had pursued—that is, for sending expeditions to the Continent instead of money— Now to be sure, a War merely with money, does not bear so hard upon a Nation, as a War with men—but then what can it effect? what is the result of this pitiful dole to beggary? an ally of a generous spirit instead of receiving it as assistance, will consider it as an offence— Now I can confide this to you—(Je puis vous le confier.) In our War with France which preceded the Peace of Tilsit, a War which we were waging for the English, since it was commenced on account of Hanover, we had proposed to the English that they should send an expedition to the Continent, which might operate as a diversion in favour of the king of Prussia, and of the king of Sweden, with whom we were then upon good terms— Instead of that, they sent a
million Sterling, to be distributed equally among the three Sovereigns; and this was the time when Lord Grenville was the Minister; and his great expedient— The generous Sentiments of the Emperor induced him to order that part of the money which was sent here to be kept in deposit; and it has been sent back to England since the commencement of this War with her— I replied that if Mr: Canning should come again into the Ministry, I did not believe that a Peace would be possible, so long as he should continue there; but that if Lord Grenville should come in; particularly if in conjunction with Lord Grey, I thought there would be a possibility of Peace—. That upon the subject of the maritime pretensions of Great-Britain, Lord Grenville was to be sure in some degree pledged, but as a Statesman of experience and judgment, he must submit to the necessity of modifying systems according to times and circumstances— That as to his emphatical attachment to the former War, it was to be remembered that he professed to consider that as a War of principles— A War against Jacobinism— A War, against the French Republic— I presumed he could not have any thing to dread at present from the Jacobinism or the Republicanism of France— The Count smiled, and said that to be sure, when one reflected upon the whole history of this French Revolution, and saw that violent Republicanism thus terminate in the greatest excess of Monarchy, it ought to be a great lesson for Mankind— I now took leave of Count Romanzoff and came home; soon after which Baron Blome, the Danish Minister called to pay me a visit— I mentioned to him the private accounts which had been received here of privateers, fitting out in the Danish Ports, and the paragraphs in the newspapers mentioning that a new ordinance for privateering was soon to be issued— He said that he could not undertake to answer that it was not so; but that he had received no indication of it from his government— That if it was so, undoubtedly it must be from a foreign instigation, and there could only have been left the alternative of doing it of their own accord or by compulsion— That he himself had advised the suspension of the privateering; and that having his Estates in Holstein, he knew how advantageous to his own Country the trade which the Americans had brought there was. But as I had told him how anxious the Americans now here, and who were going home at the opening of the Navigation were in consequence of these accounts, he said that certainly there could be no danger for them, since it was only against English trade that the privateers could be armed— But probably vessels coming into the Baltic would be molested; for the English would not suffer them to come without licences, and that his Government considered every vessel having a British licence as lawful prize— I told him that according to the orders of Council of April last the navigation to the Baltic would be open to American vessels, direct from America, without British licences, and that I did not expect that the British would add any new restriction— He appeared not to have known this modification of the orders in Council. In conclusion, as he was going away, I told him I hoped he would write to his Government, and urge them not to permit the Americans to be molested by their privateers; but he only answered by general asseverations of his own good dispositions— He told me that Princess Waezemsky was to dine with him; and what disconcerted him much was that she must dine at three O’Clock; while he was accustomed to dine at five.— I pass’d the remainder of the day at home.— In the Evening we had cards and Chess— I read Coxe’s account of the Russian Historians and Poets, and wrote most of this day’s journal.

28. Passed the day at home, excepting a walk of an hour before dinner— Mrs: Adams paid some visits in the Evening; after which we had Cards and Chess.— Mr: Fisher paid me a morning visit— The weather at length has moderated, after ten days of cold almost as severe as any we have had this Winter— We have never however had the fire made more than once a day in our chambers— In our bed-chamber, it has not been made more than five times this Winter, and in the adjoining chamber often
not more than three or four times a week— The temperature of the chamber has been from 12 to 15 of Reaumur, or from 57 to 66 of Fahrenheit’s thermometer— From 13 to 14 of Reaumur, or from 62 to 64. of Fahrenheit, is that which I find most comfortable—that is, in which no unpleasant sensation either of heat or cold is experienced.

29. Captain Beckford and Mr: Glukoff paid me a visit this morning— I walked again across the Neva upon the Ice, and returned over the Bridge— For the last month great numbers of people have been employed in cutting and carrying away masses of Ice from the river and from all the canals— The ice is from two to three feet thick, covered with a hardened crust of Snow, about a foot deep— They begin by cutting through spots perhaps 60 or 100 feet long and twenty-feet wide—and then break up this large body into cubic cakes four or five feet in length, and three or four wide— These they carry away upon one-horse sledges. Sometimes they range forty or fifty of them in a row on the canal, and leave them several days standing there— The ice is transparent, but of a greenish colour— The snow is white and opaque. Its cohesion appears perfect with the frozen water, but the line of separation between them is very distinct— I see also many persons employed in carrying through the Streets sledges filled with snow,—I suppose also for the use of ice-houses in the Summer.

30. Before I left Boston my friend Judge Davis sent me several copies of Mr: Godon’s mineralogical observations made in the neighbourhood of Boston; with a box of samples, of the rocks and stones described in it; to be presented to any Society or individual, to whom such enquiries might be interesting— I have determined to give them to the Society of Naturalists at Moscow. But wishing first to examine the collection myself and comparing it with the description, I devoted this forenoon, with Mr: Everett to that purpose— We accordingly went through the whole Collection— As we were interrupted by short visits from Mr: Montreal, and Mr: Six, it took us all the rest of the morning, so that I could not walk out— Dr: Galloway was also here— We all dined at Mr: Glukoff’s and had a Russian dinner— Fish in great abundance for the observers of lent, and flesh in equal profusion for the Americans.— On coming home this Evening I found Mr: Harris; who informed me that Mr: J. S. Smith and Mr: Maclure had this day arrived.

31. I received a Card of invitation from General Ouvaroff the Aid de Camp general of the Emperor, to attend the funeral of his wife—at the Catholic Church at 10. O’Clock this morning. On enquiry I was informed that the Ceremony would commence at the General’s House, where I went accordingly with Mr: Smith at 10— We were however too late— The Street before the house was so much crowded with Carriages, that we could not approach the gate; and at the moment when we arrived the coffin was brought into the Street, and placed under the Canopy, upon the hearse— We followed in the procession of Carriages; but when we came to the Church, it was so crowded that we could not get more than half way up the centre aisle— The funeral service was performed according to the Roman Catholic ceremonial, with very fine music of the Composition of Mozart— It was about two hours long— And from the excessive throng, we found it almost as difficult to get from the Church as it had been to get to it. The Coffin was carried from the Church and a procession of Carriages again was formed to go to Strelna where the interment was to take place— On returning home I found Mr: J. S. Smith with Mr: Maclure, and also Mr: Fisher & Mr: Graham— We dined at Mr: Rimbert’s; where we met Mr: Boucher a Professor, who is about to commence a course of lectures upon maritime and commercial Law. In the Evening, I paid visits with Mr: Harris, to the Grand Veneur Narischkin—to Count Schenk, to Mr: Grootten, the Director of a Cotton manufacture under the patronage of the Empress mother; and to the French Ambassador—all by cards— Remainder of the Evening at home.
Day— Nothing.
